qas.question: Who was an example of a disloyal samurai?
Who was an example of an excessively loyal samurai?
Some feudal lords shifted loyalties from Toyotomi to whom?
What sometimes overrode samurais' loyalty to the daimyo?

answers.text: loyalty to the Emperor was seen to have supremacy

context: Despite the rampant romanticism of the 20th century, samurai could be disloyal and treacherous (e.g., <a0_0>Akechi Mitsuhide<a0_0/>), cowardly, brave, or overly loyal (e.g., <a1_0>Kusunoki Masashige)<a1_0/>. Samurai were usually loyal to their immediate superiors, who in turn allied themselves with higher lords. These loyalties to the higher lords often shifted; for example, the high lords allied under Toyotomi Hideyoshi (豊臣秀吉) were served by loyal samurai, but the feudal lords under them could shift their support to <a2_0>Tokugawa<a2_0/>, taking their samurai with them. There were, however, also notable instances where samurai would be disloyal to their lord or daimyo, when <a3_0>loyalty to the Emperor was seen to have supremacy<a3_0/>.
